4.42.text:
- [Eric] Making photographs
today is way too easy.

8.04.text:
It's great and it's made for
this entirely new language,

15.67.text:
but for art it's become
a little too easy.

22.29.text:
I have to make obstructions,
I have to make rules

28.33.text:
to make the process
a little bit harder.

33.00.text:
I do that because it's
been one of the best ways

38.17.text:
for me to learn and
grow as an artist.

40.79.text:
I really started
thinking about, okay,

42.21.text:
what are the essential
characteristics of this medium?

45.04.text:
And I came to the conclusion
that you need a flat plane,

48.63.text:
so this two-dimensional surface,
you need light and shadow,

51.96.text: and you need a moment of time.

57.79.text:
It really makes you consider
what you're making a picture of

73.71.text:
Blue Line of Woods
started in 2010,

75.46.text:
I was living in New York at the
time, and I was seeing these

78.54.text:
really sad looking
trees on the sidewalks

82.17.text: and it was kind of hilarious

84.54.text:
and also it made
me a little sad.

87.04.text:
I started to long
for nature again.

89.25.text:
But I would see the shadows of
these trees on the sidewalks

91.88.text:
and I thought, oh this
is a really nice way

93.92.text:
to actually look at
this otherwise sad tree.

100.58.text:
I was drawn to older
technologies and the obsolete.

110.58.text:
I needed to find a way to
make really large, camera-less

113.46.text:
photographs so I found
the cheapest light
sensitive material

118.08.text: which is called blue line paper.

124.58.text:
I had a MacDowell Colony
fellowship in New Hampshire

128.12.text:
and so for six weeks I
was able to go out there

130.50.text:
in the middle of the
woods undisturbed

132.46.text:
and really start to
formalize that process.

144.38.text:
I went from three feet to six
feet to 20 feet to 40 feet

148.38.text:
they became the same scale
as the subject matter.

152.96.text:
It's really a one to one
experience with that, you can

155.29.text:
actually watch the exposure as
it goes from yellow to white.

162.17.text:
And then I bring it back to
my studio where I feed it

165.00.text:
through the processor which
just runs off of ammonia fumes

169.00.text:
and its a big tabletop processor
and it takes about a minute

172.42.text:
and it just goes through the
fumes and converts the diazo

176.08.text:
salts to this blue kind
of intense prussian blue.

182.71.text:
The paper itself is an
archival so the image will fade

186.21.text:
and it will shift in color,
it goes from the blue

189.04.text:
to a purple and so there's
something nice about that too,

195.46.text:
and the ephemerality
of the medium.

197.63.text:
And it strips away the
preciousness of the photograph

201.33.text:
and it's not just the static
image that's part of the piece,

205.83.text:
it's the performance, it's the
walk and it's the exhibition,

209.38.text:
the installation, that
eventually will go away

212.58.text:
but that's all part
of the piece now.

219.13.text:
and sort of investigating
the natural world,

224.33.text: whether it be the human scale,

226.04.text:
the macro of galaxies, or
the micro of particles,

230.38.text:
these all fall
under my interests.

233.96.text:
I think my interest in science
came out of photography,

238.21.text:
thinking about photography,
the edges of the medium,

246.71.text:
thinking about particle
protectors as cameras,

249.54.text:
so this project right now
is called Standard Stars

255.67.text:
and before if you were going
to make a picture of the sky

258.58.text:
you were going to do
it on this glass plate.

262.50.text:
and efficient way
to map the universe.

265.29.text:
This institution, the Pisgah
Astronomical Research Institute

268.46.text:
is going to collect
and digitize these

271.25.text:
and then make them
available for everyone.

273.96.text:
And I discovered there's a
treasure trove of these images.

278.33.text:
On my second and third trips
I brought a scanner with me,

282.17.text:
I'm interested in this where
there weren't too many stars

286.25.text:
or maybe a cloud or an airplane
interrupted the exposure,

291.58.text:
or the assistant
dropped the plate

293.33.text:
or didn't put enough
developer in the tray

296.79.text:
Those are the marks of
the human as I think a lot

300.79.text:
of my practice is about finding
that evidence of humanity

310.08.text:
So I look for the fingerprints,
I look for the accidents

313.08.text:
because that's something
I can relate to.

315.42.text:
I can not relate to
a star or a galaxy,

317.63.text:
I have no idea
what its scale is.

319.79.text:
But I can totally relate to
dropping a plate on the ground

322.13.text:
and then being like, oh
my God what did I do?

325.88.text:
So that's kind of what I'm
trying to get at in the work.

332.88.text:
One of them, the labels,
right, someone, yeah,

336.58.text:
stamped standard stars, so
that's kind of the title

341.29.text:
that I'm taking
from it right now.

343.50.text:
'Cause it's so, it's
kind of poetic, it's nice

352.50.text:
but when you're looking
at millions of them,

354.38.text:
obviously some are going to
be less amazing than others

357.13.text:
so there's going to be this
category of like normal,

359.50.text:
just standard stars
and I love that.

364.75.text:
But yeah, someone wrote
broken on here, clouds,

368.67.text:
they didn't even write down
like all that other stuff,

370.83.text:
they're just like whatever,
clouds got in the way.

374.96.text: I want you to think heads,

376.67.text:
visualize heads and try and
use your telekinetic powers.

381.42.text:
Gut feeling came out around
2011, gut is an acronym

389.33.text:
gut feelings taking a
lot of different forms,

392.04.text:
I did a residency at the Bakken
Museum here in Minneapolis

395.08.text:
where I was photographing
children experiencing

397.38.text:
static electricity
for the first time,

399.92.text:
I've done these pop
up experimental tests
at the state fair

404.08.text:
and the Walker Art Center
where I've had people try

406.54.text:
to control the
outcomes of coin flips

408.54.text: and dice rolls using their mind.

410.67.text:
It's really becoming
more of a philosophy

413.42.text:
than a body of work
for me at this point.

417.17.text:
In 2013 I went to visit an
archive of the recently deceased

423.42.text:
Nobel Prize winning
physicist Donald Glaser

426.75.text:
and I became
interested in his work

428.54.text:
because of his invention
of the bubble chamber.

432.63.text:
right now are from these
bubble chamber images

438.00.text:
We've been using toys and
games to reanimate them,

440.38.text:
so we're using dominoes
and dice and rubik's cubes

443.21.text:
to bring back these
old scientific images

447.33.text: and make them feel alive again.

475.75.text:
I really do believe in
the work part of it,

481.29.text: and that is meditative for me.

485.13.text:
I've tried laying in a hammock
before and it's relaxing

487.33.text:
for about 15 minutes and after
that I'm an anxious pile.

492.63.text:
I can't not do
that. Not make work.
